Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2010 09:18PM ShirleyHughes wrote: BTW, I lied.  I do eat some processed foods.  I know it's horrible for ya, but sometimes it's just easier.  I hate worrying over every single thing I put in my mouth....like the ice cream cake I made when my kids were here visiting....yum!   However, we only had little pieces. Everytime I eat a salad I wonder what pesticide I'm eating.  Sure would have liked some of your dad's milk.  I remember when they delivered it (when I was young) to our door.  There was cream on top.  And it was WHOLE milk...LOL This is so easy to make.  I know it's bad for you...but having it once in a while is fine (I think).  You could make this for Dr. McDreamy.  Nah, it would melt because the heat in the examing room would be accelerated by your heavy breathing.  Oh, and there's a video on there to show ya how to make it.  I didn't use the foil.  I used my tupperware cake keeper. http://www.kraftrecipes.com/recipes/oreo-fudge-ice-cream-106562.aspx OREO & Fudge Ice Cream Cake       What You Need! 1/2 cup hot fudge ice cream topping, warmed 1 tub  (8 oz.) COOL WHIP Whipped Topping, thawed, divided 1 pkg. (3.9 oz.) JELL-O Chocolate Instant Pudding 8   OREO Cookies, chopped (about 1 cup) 12 vanilla ice cream sandwiches Make It! POUR fudge topping into medium bowl. Whisk in 1 cup COOL WHIP. Add dry pudding mix; stir 2 min. Stir in chopped cookies. ARRANGE 4 ice cream sandwiches, side-by-side, on 24-inch-long piece of foil; top with half the COOL WHIP mixture. Repeat layers. Top with remaining sandwiches. Frost top and sides with remaining COOL WHIP. Bring up foil sides; double fold top and ends to loosely seal packet. FREEZE 4 hours or until firm. Kraft Kitchens Tips Note The consistency of fudge topping can vary depending on what brand you purchase. If the fudge topping mixture is too thick to spread easily, stir in 1/4 cup milk. Special Extra Prepare using Neapolitan ice cream sandwiches. Size-Wise Since this indulgent ice cream cake makes 12 servings, it is the perfect dessert to serve at your next party.

Boyfriends............my dd (who has the cat) is looking at houses.  She lives with her boyfriend, but she wants to move out and he doesn't know yet.  She doesn't want to hurt him, and would rather at least find the house and have a binding contract before she tells him.  She'll tell him they can still date, but living together was a mistake...she moved in too soon.  This is the first guy she's ever lived with and I hope it's the last.  Like I tell her...there's no one perfect out there.  Just us women!

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2010 02:49PM ShirleyHughes wrote: Jenny, first of all their are resources for people that are "underinsured."  One great place to try is HealthWell Foundation.  They will help with expensive drugs. I'm assuming that you are postmenopausal since you're taking Femara.  Hopefully that will kick in and help control the mets.  When I was recently diagnosed with mets to a vertabra, my oncologist switched me to Aromasin which seems to be working.  I have not started Zometa yet. I can truly understand how you feel...being scared and feeling all alone.  Please do take the advice of the ladies here and ask your oncologist for a prescription for an anti-anxiety drug.  Also, an antidepressant may be something else you need. I've been going to Duke for years to see a gyno.  And a few other doctors.  I always had my mammos there.  I had one in March of '04, and found my lump that same year in December.  Perhaps if I had been vigilant and had done SBEs I would have found it sooner...but that's in the past.  The little over two hour drive is worth it.  I did my chemo there, but did my rads here because it was not financially feasible to stay in Durham a week at a time, plus I had a cat and a dog.  And, my dog was not well.  My husband does go with me each time.  That is one busy place.  They are building a new cancer center.  I did not go on the computer researching because I was petrified.  I let anyone else who wanted to do that for me.  My daughter would give me the good news ONLY...LOL  This is not easy, and I can only imagine that you would like to crawl in bed and sleep to the awakening of a bad dream (nightmare).  My advice for you is not to read any statistics....you ARE NOT a statistic.  Do get a second opinion if you do not feel comfortable with your team.  No one should have used the word "palliative."  That word has a negative connotation for those of us who do not understand this disease and how many treatments there are that can help stabilize it or put it in remission.  However, I believe the gals here explained all of that to you very well. Keep coming back here for support.  Never feel badly about posting anything.  Rant, stomp your feet...just get things off your chest.  Hopefully that will receive some of your stress. Take care and let us hear from you. Shirley

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2010 08:36AM ShirleyHughes wrote: My horrrible news...we got our cat,  Mitzi, from a shelter a couple of hours away.  I saw this perfectly beautiful cat and had to have her.  Then we lost our other adopted cat, Gizmo, to cancer.  We also had a pom, Tasha, who we lost after my mastectomy.  That left only Mitzi.  I took in a ferel cat, Prissy, for Mitzi that I had been feeding (there were three and then two)  That didn't work.  So we adopted Cleo from a shelter.  That was good.  Then the pal of Prissy, Cleo (the other ferel cat) was taken in for Prissy cuz they had been friends.  Neither ferel was happy to be in here, but I told them they would be happy when they settled in.  THIS MORNING I FOUND MY BEAUTIFUL MITZI DEAD!  I didn't see her last night and I knew she couldnt have gotten outside.  I looked in the living room, caller her name, and there she was.  She was a precious baby.  I have three other cats, but it still hurts soooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo bad.  My dh is taking her to have her cremated. No, I couldn't work in a shelter that put animals down after they've had them so long.  But I admire those who are so loving and can do this.  My heart is breaking.  What happened to my fur baby?
Posts.Title: Progression in liver and bones :-( konakat dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2010 11:15AM ShirleyHughes wrote: My brain is so fuzzy.  Correction...we adopted Abby and Cleo was the other ferel cat. I didn't mean to hijack this thread. But thank you for your kind words.  Anyone who's an animal lover knows the feeling of losing their baby.  I've lost too many as I'm sure many of you have. Dreamwriter...breast cancer.  Oh how awful. We don't think of animals getting bc.  My Tasha (dog) gave us a scare when she was around 4 years old.  I didn't have her spayed.  She developed lumps in her breast.  The doc thought it could be breast cancer.  The surgery proved otherwise, thank God.  She was immediately spayed while in surgery.  In case anyone doesn't know, when you have a female animal they need to be spayed in order to prevent bc.  That is if you are not going to breed them.  I suppose they can also get bc even if they are spayed. Dreamwriter, I'm sorry for your loss too.  I have cried more than once right here on this board (not literally..lol) when people have announced the loss of one of their precious pets.  I am so happy there are so many animal lovers.  Elizabeth, what a good Mommy you are.  Do you know that many people would put down their cat if it had the same problems as yours?  Gizmo was a diabetic cat.  I had to give him insulin shots.  One person from my primary's office thought it was great that I didn't put him down, but instead gave him his insulin shots.  I thought to myself...what?  But it's true that some people would not want to be bothered.  And I love the idea that your cat is a very SENIOR cat and you still are giving her LOVE and treatments to keep her alive. Okay, I am "unhijacking" this thread.  And thanks again for the kind words.

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2010 08:08PM ShirleyHughes wrote: If I had chosen reconstruction, my surgeon said I would wait about 8 months.  He did the tram.  I chose not to have reconstruction.  As for a mastectomy and lumpectomy my choice was limited.  I did neo-adjuvant chemo shrinking the tumor to about half.  It was 4.5 cm.  Also, there was another tumor in another quadrant of my breast.  After doing the MRI to see how much the tumor shrunk, the other tumor did not show up.  So, my surgeon had me talk to the rad onc.  We could have done a wire guided CT scan....blah, blah...and I said, no thanks...mast will do.  Well, indeed that tumor, 1 cm., was still there.  Even if we did a "double" lumpectomy, the aesthetics would not have come out well. I go to Duke.  So, yes, there are different opinions.  Perhaps my surgeon has changed his mind.  I rather doubt it about the immediate reconstruction because of the rads.  I had my surgery done in 2005.

Thanks again and may God bless you and your wife. Shirley

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 02:36AM ShirleyHughes wrote: Rebecca, I cry as you describe the loss of your sister.  I have no magic words to take your pain away.  Try to remember the good times.  I know that's hard right now because it's so soon after your loss.  It makes me happy for you that you two were so close.  The closeness you two had does not happen in every family.  Sisters are special.  I have three daughters who are close to one another.  It is not hard for them say those three important words, I love you.  It would be just as devastating for one of them to lose their sister.  You and your family will be in my thoughts and prayers.  They say time heals all wounds.  Sometimes time passes too slowly when the pain is just as strong as it was yesterday.  Hugs, Shirley

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 12:33PM ShirleyHughes wrote: Just had to add my two cents.  Yesterday I finally PMed the mods asking that IBCspouse and Roctobermom be "unbanned."  They were unfairly banned for life.  I believe IBCspouse only had two posts "removed by the community."  And then, WHAMO, he tried to sign on and received the sweet little note that he was banned forever.  His wife is now suffering from skin mets.  And, Roctobermom, she's been here for a long time.  Her posts were not breaking any rules.  She's banned for life.  Why? I can tell you why.  SOME of the dem ladies came on a couple of nights in the late hours.  I checked out to see who had logged on and when.  At those times they went on the "report this post" spree.  For no reason I had several posts removed.  No rules broken...only their rules.  I could post my deleted post because I have saved them.  You'd see the rules were not broken..you may have disagreed with MY OPINION just as much as I disagreed with their opinions.  HOWEVER, I DID NOT delete any of their posts..,perhaps one a long time ago.  On that late night spree many other posts were moved from other repub girls.  I was banned, but not for life.  Some that were banned are still on restriction without any explanation from the mods are without any answers via PMs.  I don't know if I'm on restriction because I haven't posted enough since all this happened.  I sent many emails to mods because I could not log on and PM them.  I never received one explanation as to why I was banned UNTIL I was informed that all the political threads were being taken down.  In my opinion (and it's ONLY my opinion), this was the goal of the dem girls.  What I find very strange is I know one member who posted on the dem thread that has removed her comments.  I won't give out any names, but she knows who she is.  I ask WHY?  What are you ashamed of? Nicki, I am so sorry you are going through this.  I am sorry that the mods did not lift your ban.  I wonder who reported you.  Whoever it was in my opinion has a big emotional problem.  I know here at BCO you have many friends and you just wanted to reconnect with them.  You have all of our support. Indigoblue, you are right and {{{{{{{{{{{BIG HUGS!}}}}}}}}}}}}}}!!!!!!!!!!!  Love ya, girl! Nicki, I will book mark your blog and also go to the other NEW forums to keep up with your journey.  I hope you see how many women here love you.  Your humor, your knowledge, your caring...being JUST YOU is what we love about you. To all the metsters, don't feel like you have to give up your support from these ladies because of us who have been treated unfairly.  You need to be here.  You have created a bond with these women.  But, of course, there is also support in the other forums that have been posted.  You can use all of them if you want.  Shirley

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2010 02:42PM ShirleyHughes wrote: I think many of us are crying for Elizabeth, her children/family AND ourselves.  I was dxd a little over a year ago with progression to one vertebra.  I had scans done and now it's in two more spots....rib and sternum.  I have scans again in Feb.  I say this because I have put my worries about this mess on the back burner...denial.  However, in recent days I've been thinking about life and the peeks and valleys and curves we go through never thinking this could happen to me.  And, a very wealthy woman with everything ended up with a deadly disease.  It so saddens me that she didn't get to see her children grow physically and emotionally.  I angers me that there's been no real breakthrough for treating breast cancer. On the other hand, we need to focus on the treatment available.  There are women on this board who have had substantial improvement.  I guess what I am trying to say is we need to be strong for each other.  However, it's also good that we can express our fears to those that understand. RIP, Elizabeth.  I've had to let this sudden event soak in.

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2010 04:20PM ShirleyHughes wrote: I know how you feel....scared to death!  With my initial dx I had a bone scan and CT scan.  My liver and adrenal gland showed a spot.  My onc said he would not have picked it up, but of course the radiologist did.  Instead of a liver biopsy he instead ordered a PET scan.  Both were benign.  I have since been dxd with one spot on a vertabra.  And those same spots on the adrenal gland and liver are still there, unchanged and, of course, ARE benign.  My first dx was in 2004 and stage IV 2009. Good luck and DO take an drug for anxiety. Shirley

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2007 12:44AM - edited Sep 21, 2007 03:48AM by ShirleyHughes Geeta, first of all thank you so much for breaking this tearful news.  I will be praying that your broken heart will heal soon.   Shelli, you will be so missed by so many people.  You were/are such an inspiration to all of us.  I just hope that I can be as brave as you, my dear sweet little one.  You are wrapped in the arms of Jesus.  No more pain or tears.  Your legacy will live on in your darling children.   To Karl, my dear, what can I say.  You have lost your friend, wife, lover and the mother of your children.  I know you did not want to see Shelli in pain any longer.  It is never easy to say goodbye.  I pray God will wipe away your tears and give you peace.  Know that Shelli IS in peace with no more pain and all tears wiped from her eyes.   To Shelli's dear children.  Your mommy will live on in your hearts.  She will be looking over you at all times.  She loved you so much.  She fought a good fight, unselfishly, for you her dear children.    To Sandy.  My heart aches for you.  I cannot imagine losing one of my girls.  They are about the same age as Shelli.  You were there for her at all times.  Her spirit was and will remain so strong.  You, my dear, raised a fine young woman for whom I'm sure you are so proud.  Shelli was loved by so many people across this nation and from other countries.    No words can express the feelings any of us have for the loss of your dear daughter, wife and mother.  She was a beautiful person inside and out.  I'm sure tears have flowed for Shelli from everyone on this board.  We all know she's in a better place.    I leave you with this song.   No More Night http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nDQijZ0OpaU&mode=related&search=

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 04:51PM ShirleyHughes wrote: Yan, I have to jump in here. I believe your wife does know the seriousness of her illness.  If not, she wouldn't have worries.  I do not believe she's living in fantasy land not knowing this dreadful disease can come back with a vengeance.  I have not "joined" the stage IV ladies because my head is still in the sand.  I come here and read now and then.  I find I cannot, for myself, read this thread all the time.  It depresses me.  I have one lesion on one vertebra dxd, I believe, in Oct.  I had my three month CT scan yesterday and it still on showed that one spot.  I will have a CT and bone scan in two months. I said that to say I don't want to know every detail.  I know this can come back worse than it is right now.  I had a friend who died from this in November of 2008 and I saw what happened.  She was the strongest woman...she fought up until the end.  She was stage IV for about 10 years before it raised it's ugly, stupid head. I'm sorry if I cannot be of much support right now.  Call me a wimp.  Call me selfish.  I do care about everyone here.  I knew from my dx that I would likely have this visitor come back.  But, I didn't dwell on it or I would have gone crazy.  I'm sure one day I will be posting here all the time, but for now I just can't.  Forgive me. So, Yan, I understand what you are doing.  I'm not one to look up stats or negative crap.  I have to try to stay as positive as I can.  And, I have three grown daughters who do their share of worrying and just want it GONE!  I have explained to them that it will never be gone even it I'm NED..there will be cells lurking. Take care of your sweet wife.  You are a treasure. Shirley

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2010 02:49PM ShirleyHughes wrote: With my first go-around with AC, I remember that night I woke up so nauseas.  I felt like I wanted to throw up, but couldn't.  It may have been the food I ate that evening.  Marybe, are they giving your friend a steroid to take for about three days after each treatment?  That can make one HUNGRY!  Also, I believe it's for nausea.  They also put in the IV for premeds.  Some gals "crash" about the fifth or sixth day.  The Zofran worked great for me.  They also gave me compazine for in between Zofran.  So, I had no real issues with nausea after that first night. I kept saltines next to me.  I usually drink tea...did not taste good.  I drank gingerale instead.  It wasn't AS sweet as 7-up....water...yuck!  I really can't remember what I ate.  I don't remember craving much of anything.  Butterfly, glad your appetite is good.  Yep, don't worry about it.  Hope you continue to feel pretty well.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2010 04:24PM ShirleyHughes wrote: Caall1234, I am in the same dilemma.  So far I only have one spot on my spine.  I go back in 2 months for another CT and bone scan...just had CT scan about a week ago.  I went to my dentist yesterday.  I already knew that I need my wisdom tooth pulled.  And, I was sure I had another one that had to be pulled...decay under a crown.  Now, to replace the one with the crown...would take a bridge...very expensive.  But, I must at least have these two teeth pulled before even going on Zometa.  I have a very dry mouth due to some meds I take which can cause gum line cavities.  I have had other cavities under crowns.  This just scares the heck out of me.  I am now using a fluoride toothpaste nightly after first brushing with regular toothpaste.  You do not rinse your mouth after the fluoride paste...just spit.  If you're having any of these issues with cavities, ask your dentist for the fluoride toothpaste.  The hygienist said if I should get a cavity the fluroide would keep it small.  Good luck! Shirley

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2010 07:02PM ShirleyHughes wrote: Great article.  I happen to see it under "active topics" when I signed on. IMO, I have been living with the glass half full.  What I mean by that is I didn't worry every day that I'd get mets (which I call "progression" instead of mets because I like to stay in denial land as I have told EVERYONE).  Anyway, I had a regular onc visit and she ended up wanting me to have a CT scan and bone scan.  Long story.  She wasn't looking for anything in the bones..I believe she order that because my calcium level was a little elevated..she said since I was going for a CT scan she'd throw in a bone scan the same day.  YIPPEE!  Anyway, after having both scans and after each scan reported I had a spot on one of my vertabra I decided I wanted a biopsy.  It was postive.  Hmmmmmmmm....positive.  I was just thinking positive isn't such a good description of bad news...LOL I have another CT scan this month.  So far I'm not sitting around worrying.  I'm sure when it comes closer to time for that scan I'll HAVE to worry.  And, of course if there's more progression we'll see just how non-chalant I'll stay. All that positive stuff....no one can be made to feel positive if it ain't there. I don't know if I was positive or just didn't worry about it.  Like I said..denial land is where I want to be and I told my onc if I had known she was going to put me through these tests I would not have complained about my arm...LE arm.

Posts.Title: Well, I finally made my announcement at work... Fitztwins ShirleyHughes

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2012 08:30PM ShirleyHughes wrote: Very good question.  I don't know the answer. When I was dxd with mets it was by accident...no pain.  She decided to do a CT and bone scan after I complained about my LE arm..armpit feeling swollen.  Since I had positive nodes she wanted to check it out to be sure...then she decided to do bone scan as well.  Perhaps it was because my calcium  was a bit elevated....she also did blood work for parathyroid.  Anway, to our surprise the CT and bone scan picked up one lesion on my L1.  I wanted a biopsy so we could be positive and also to know the pathology of the lesion. Sometimes she does CT and bone scans.  This time (after six months) she's only doing a CT scan.  I asked why not the bone scan also.  It seems the bone scan picks up new lesions that the CT does not.  But these scans are tricky.  She says sometimes it could be a lesion that is healing.  I do know if the CT picks up something new it will suggest a bone scan.  These tests confuse me.  She tires to explain it to me and I get more confused.  Last time my bone scan said "stable".  The CT said something different...could have been a lesion healing..I think it said sclerotic something or another.  I don't have my report in front of me. There's not one set standard.  It's all scary.  If I had to go by my pain level I would say I still wouldn't know and I found out about my single bone met Sept. 2009 (I think).  Of course we all know that the CT can pick up lesions in the soft tissue.  My sciatica bothers me from time to time, but I had that before I knew I had mets.  Or, something else may hurt just a little and I get all stressed.  Then it goes away.  So, I don't know what to think.  Sorry, I'm of no help.  Just as confused as ever!
Posts.Title: CT scan was stable for bone mets, is that a good indication? Fitztwins SPAMgirl

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2008 10:24PM ShirleyHughes wrote: Thanks, berries.  I needed to hear something positive about the supposed bad foods we eat.  I'm not as knowledgeable, nor do I always understand the "workings" of the ole body.  You're quote below and this is what's getting me confused when I read the "study"...likes it BAD, but it MAY NOT be bad.  Make sense?  Of course not. LOL "A compound or food ingredient can be estrogenic, and bind to an estrogen receptor, but you don't know if it's an antagonist or agonist unless you do a functional study.  A lot of the "phytoestrogenic" foods listed may actually be protective by binding to the receptors and blocking activity.  That's what makes it all so complex.  So some phytoestrogens may be a good thing!"  I'm still going to take my tumeric.  I don't take as much as Constantine advised.  I take my one little capsule of green tea instead of being a good girl and drinking it.  Before this bc journey is over we'll all be doctors, researchers or nutritionists.  Shirley

Jesus said:  (John 14:26-27) "But the Helper, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in My name, He will teach you all things, and bring to your remembrance all things that I said to you. {27} "Peace I leave with you, My peace I give to you; not as the world gives do I give to you. Let not your heart be troubled, neither let it be afraid."
Posts.Title: Can't Walk.... Headed to ER TripleNeg booklady

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 06:26PM ShirleyHughes wrote: First to RobinWendy.  Heck we all get in this funks and something just stirs that anger.  And I believe it's the anger that this stupid disease is made too pretty.  When I got breast cancer I wasn't like....soooooo concerned or overwhelmed by it.  Why?  Because I knew absolutely NOTHING about this dease.  Thought I'd do whatever and all would be well.  After visinting the onc for the first time he sort of scared me into knowing that this can "travel."  And, it seems like people think if you live past 5 years with bc....IT'S OVER!  YOU'RE CURED!  Let's find it early...well how many women do we know who have found it early have still progressed to stage IV.  Now, I'm not advocating not doing mammos.  But, unless you are one of your family members or friends have had this disease MOST people do not know how sneaky it is. I have nothing against the color pink.  I love pink.  But I think it's time to let people know the TRUTH about this disease.  I remember sometime back when a commercial was on, and the woman was saying to her bc sisters that it can come back, some people did not like that.  I thought it was good and it was honest.  I believe this disease is the "good" one to get for those who do not understand it.  It's complicated, sneaky and I'm sick of women dying.  Too many lovely women on this board have succumb to this ugliness of a disease. I believe most of us grieved for Patrick Swayze with his Pancreatic Cancer (another horrible one...and ovarian cancer).  We saw a virile man go down to nothing while fighting with all of his might.  He was doing his show with no pain meds.  What a strong example.  I hate cancer, period!
